Kapal Asal Norwegia Dibajak di Pantai Barat Afrika
04 Nov 2019, 06:00 by Non Koresponden , Suci Sekarwati
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Sebuah Kapal pengangkut asal Norwegia pada Sabtu pagi, 2 November 2019 dimasuki perompak saat melewati wilayah lepas pantai barat Afrika. Para perompak menculik kapten dan delapan awal kapal.
J.J Ugland, perusahaan pengiriman asal Norwegia, mengkonfirmasi peristiwa pembajakan ini pada Minggu, 3 November. Total 9 orang disandera dalam insiden ini.
Sembilan orang yang ditahan dibawa ke lokasi rahasia dan tidak dapat dipastikan apakah mereka ditahan untuk suatu tebusan atau tidak. Menurut Asosiasi Pemilik Kapal Norwegia, semua kru yang diculik berasal dari Filipina. Tidak dipublikasikan identitas para korban yang diculik.
Kapal bernama MV Bonita diketahui menunggu tempat berlabuh di pelabuhan Cotonou untuk melepaskan pengiriman gypsum ketika para perompak naik dan menculik awak kapal.
Berdasarkan laporan situs DN yang dikutip mirror, Senin 4 November, kru yang tersisa segera menghubungi pihak berwenang setempat dan mengirimkan peringatan darurat ke kapal-kapal terdekat lainnya.
Kru tersisa diketahui telah merapat bersama MV Bonita di kota pelabuhan Cotonou, pusat ekonomi utama negara itu.
“Tim tanggap darurat Ugland yang menangani situasi ini melakukan prosedur ketika kondisi darurat terjadi. Mereka segera menghubungi pihak berwenang terkait. Keluarga awak kapal yang diculik telah dihubungi dan akan diberi tahu perkembangan beritanya oleh Ugland,” tulis perusahaan pemilik kapal.
Melansir cnn, sebuah laporan yang dirilis pada Juli 2019 oleh organisasi nirlaba, Internasional Maritime Bureau (IMB) menyebut Teluk Guinea adalah area rawan pembajakan dunia. Sedangkan laut di sekitar Afrika barat tetap yang paling berbahaya di dunia dalam hal pembajakan.
Laporan ini juga mengatakan 73 persen dari semua penculikan di laut dan 92 persen dari penyanderaan terjadi di Teluk Guinea di lepas pantai Nigeria, Guinea, Togo, Benin dan Kamerun dari Januari hingga Juni tahun ini.

Norwegian Ship Hijacked on the West Coast of Africa
04 Nov 2019, 06:00 by Non Correspondent, Suci Sekarwati
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - A Norwegian transport ship on the morning of Saturday, November 2, 2019 was entered by pirates as it passed through the west coast of Africa. The pirates kidnap the captain and eight early ships.
J.J Ugland, a Norwegian shipping company, confirmed this piracy event on Sunday, November 3. A total of 9 people were taken hostage in this incident.
Nine people who were arrested were taken to a secret location and it is uncertain whether they were detained for a ransom or not. According to the Norwegian Shipowners Association, all of the abducted crew came from the Philippines. The identities of the abductees were not made public.
The ship named MV Bonita is known to be waiting for a berth in the port of Cotonou to release gypsum shipments when the pirates board and abduct the crew.
Based on a DN website report quoted by mirror, Monday 4 November, the remaining crew immediately contacted local authorities and sent emergency warnings to other nearby ships.
The remaining crew are known to have docked with MV Bonita in the port city of Cotonou, the country's main economic center.
"The Ugland emergency response team that handled this situation carried out procedures when an emergency occurred. They immediately contacted the relevant authorities. The family of the abducted crew member has been contacted and will be notified of the progress of the news by Ugland, "wrote the ship owner's company.
Cnn launch, a report released in July 2019 by a non-profit organization, the International Maritime Bureau (IMB) said the Gulf of Guinea is an area prone to piracy in the world. While the seas around western Africa remain the most dangerous in the world in terms of piracy.
The report also said 73 percent of all kidnappings at sea and 92 percent of hostages took place in the Gulf of Guinea off the coast of Nigeria, Guinea, Togo, Benin and Cameroon from January to June this year.
